This game was a little bit of a surprise..  I don't usually get much into tycoon type games, though I have fond memories of Theme Hospital from a few years back, and I guess Rollercoaster Tycoon, so my experience isn't great to compare this to others in the genre.   That being said, I find this game a great deal of fun.

There are two core elements to the game;  a Logistical puzzle, and, a decent strategic/business simulator.  I'll cover these separately.

The first part is what you mostly see in the pretty screenshots - you need to construct assembly lines that transform raw biological substances (insect parts, plants, etc) into finished pharmaceuticals.   There are a good number of different medicines you can manufacture and each one has vastly different requirements.  You need to purchase a variety of machines to transform the product as it moves along the belt from the 'in window' to the exit.   Some machines strengthen effects and some dilute them.  Other machines are used to combine two ingredients, to analyze a finished drug, to modify or rearrange effects, and to package the final product.  All of these machines have different 'in' and 'out' slots that will need to be matched up via conveyor belts in the correct order.   At first this can be a little daunting and frustrating, especially when you attempt to 'upgrade' a drug to a more powerful version, and some trial and error is required.   That said, it's great fun once you learn the basics, and quite rewarding when you smooth everything out.

The second part of the game is the business sim.  This is probably standard fare for these types of games, but again I'm not experienced enough to provide a good comparison.  In order to succeed you'll need to carefully manage your expenses - buildings and expansions, machines, drug ingredients, research, and exploration all require money, and while you can take out loans, this will quickly sink you if you don't have steady cashflow coming in.   There are competitors who are trying to make a profit as well, and deciding which drugs will provide the best returns can be a challenge.  You must invest time and money into research in order to unlock better machines and make your existing ones more efficient.  You also must send explorers out to discover new substances that can be transformed or combined into new types of drugs.  Random events can have impact on supply and demand as well, so it pays to keep an eye on news popups.

There is a good tutorial, which introduces you to game concepts as you play so you don't get overwhelmed.  After that, a series of 'missions' of advancing difficulties keeps the game fresh.   I can't speak to the replayability of the game as I'm nowhere near completing the core missions yet, but I believe there Is a sandbox mode once you've mastered all the basics.  The missions themselves can take from 15 minutes to a couple hours, depending on the difficulty and how focused you are.

Big Pharma's art style can be described as cartoony and colorful.  It really reminded me of a less silly version of theme hospital, but aside from the graphics (and upbeat music) there aren't may other similarities between these two games.  One nice feature is the ability to 'paint' your factory - with various primary hues and patterns.  This could be useful to customize different product lines or processes on each line, or just pretty things up to your own tastes.

I recommend this to anyone who enjoys casual business sims and puzzles.  Big Pharma succeeds well at both, and I found it well worth the price of 24.99, though I was fortunate enough to get it on sale.

Having played this game in (pre-Steam) alpha and beta for over 150 hours I can say ... it's amazing!

So, what is it about?

- Create a perfect, smooth running production cycle
- Are you going for a cheap medication, try to appeal the mass-market, make a quick buck?
- Do you want to perfection it, research side-effects, minimize them and improve?
- Beat your competition by patenting the big cures? Maybe YOU are the guy curing Ebola, getting rich and famous?
- Research new ingredients, new cures, new machines, new developments, new production methods
- Send your scouts and scientists on month-long missions to find that rare beetle somewhere in the Arctic ice or learn how to use that new technology you need to unlock a fourth or fifth level of an ingredient.
- Expand, start with new ingredients, new cures, do it all over again!

It's a sandbox game and feels a lot more like Transport Tycoon or Infinifactory than Theme Hospital, you have your input (a plant, an insect, any kind of biological source), you refine it, mix it, filter it, strengthen or weaken specific effects, create a smooth running cycle with dozens of machines or steps in between, then export it as a medication in various forms. Pills or syringes? All your choice. Then you get rid of the side-effects, mix in other incredients, improve, get your A+ cure out and feel proud!

Play with or without competition, maybe you just like to make it look good and not fight with other companies? Your call!

If you like games like Infinifactory / SpaceChem or Transport Tycoon you will love this game.
If you expect a simulation where small changes can affect the outcome on the long run you will love this game.
If you expect the humor of curing patients like you did in Theme Hospital, this game might appeal, but wont fill that need.

Overall it's a big recommendation if you like slow moving steady games, it'll often take hours to set things up well-running, and it's all about patience.

So I've been playing since the early access non-steam beta came out and I've put about 30 hours into this game before this release and I honestly have to say while I like the idea it has some really bad core problems that all stem from it's use of luck.

Basically this is a puzzle game with a enormous amount of randomness thrown into it and those are two things that rarely work well together. The game is more or less about completing scenario's with tiers of set goals and two months ago I made a rather long post on /r/bigpharmagame that explained why it's not done very good well overall.

The short version is basically everything you need is random. The amount of space you start to build in is random, the drug effects you start with are random, the effects on those drugs are random, the order you unlock new drugs is random, the products your competitors will make are random. The only non-random things are how much money you start with and your overall goal for the scenario. Which leads to many many MANY unwinnable situations, e.g; It's possible to play a scenario were you have to produce certain medicines within a certain time period and random chance will put the drug you need so far down the research list that there's no possible way to even get to it let alone produce anything with it before the time expires.

To put it into something that most people would understand; pretend your playing StarCraft 2 but the amount of SCV's you started with was random, so was the amount of vespene geysers, mineral patches and how much was in them.  With me so far? So YOU might start with 2 SCV's, 4 vespene geysers and 3 mineral patches, while your opponent starts with 10 SCV's, 2 vespene geysers and 20 mineral patches. Now ontop of that also make all the unit costs and research a random number as well. Do you see why this is bad now?

It's basically a requirement to restart a scenario over and over again til you get the space and favorable drugs you need if you plan on getting anything but the bronze completion. Even if you get a favorable start, you still might need to end up restarting anyway because you may have had 2 of the drugs you needed for the 3 pills you had to produce but sadly #3 is the very last one your explorers can find.

Overall it's what killed the game for me. If there was set drugs with set effects with set starting positions on the board then I wouldn't have had nearly any of the complaints I did. But overall you spend more time restarting then actually playing the game unless your content to bust your ♥♥♥ for bronze the whole way through, riding the waves of luck.

Big Pharma is a ...Well, lets just say it outright, it's not a game about being a large scale megacorporation producing a massive amount of drugs and cornering the market. It's not a simulation of medical pills and pharma companies, and it certainly is not a game about the overall management of such a company or the simulation of such a thing.

It makes promises that it can not keep. You will get little strategy, severely abstracted simulation, and very limited management. 'Big Pharma' is not about anything big at all.

Instead, it is a small scale game that is essentially a puzzle about optimising chains of machines to produce a desired output, in a randomised building area of random size, with random ingredients that have random effects. If you like that, then good for you. You will probably enjoy this one, but for the rest of us who are after the other 'features' it proclaims to have..

The simulation is basic to the point where I wonder if it is a simulation at all. Diseases have a set number of sufferers or a set cycle/increase of sufferers and your management is limited purely to the supply lines, machines, and conveyor belts. Everything else is abstracted to the degree that I wonder why it was even included in the game, and many times adds nothing except a timer you need to wait on before you can continue working your belts.

The challenge, and main gameplay is more alike a puzzle.
Fit machines in the (random) building you have to have your (random) ingredients produce an optimal effect for maximum profit. Nearly all the gameplay is about optimising your conveyor belts and machines, which will be frustrating to you because the machines come only in one form with 4 facings. You can not make a symmetrical and effective supply line, and conveyors can not go over or under eachother. You get a limited amount of (Randomly placed) input/output areas to connect to, and often you will not have space for just about anything more than a basic machine.
Employees never have to walk in, out, or do anything in your building, they are merely an animation that is part of the machine. Research and exploration happens somewhere else. You never see your scientists or explorers except in a menu where you send them out.

If this game was only purely the production tab, was honest about its size and content and somewhere between 5-10 dollars, then it would be great. But as it currently stands I just can not reccommend it for its price.
The conveyor belt optimising puzzling is nice, and I will likely play it a few more times just for that, but that is all there is to the game. There is no 'improving the lives of millions', there is no 'getting rid of disease', there is no real management or simulation of a 'pharmaceutical conglomerate' here. The challenge scenarios are jokes, the rival corporations are jokes, and the whole 'business sim' part that it talks about in the About This Game" part of the store are jokes.

This is a conveyor belts puzzle with shiny graphics

reviewText:
VERY well made game! I had a sneaky suspician that this was going to be a good game (from what I'd researched prior to its launch), but I was surprised to find that it was much better than I had expected.

See the TL;DR read section at bottom if you want just the quick notes.

I'm trying to keep the in-depth review as brief as possible, but it's very difficult...there's so much to say about this game.

The Good
1. GAMEPLAY

You start, grow, and manage a pharmaceutical company. You control every aspect of it such as production lines, research and development, budget (purchases, importing ingredients, payroll, cost of production), meeting market demand, etc. This is a pharmaceutical tycoon game and it gives you plenty of options and features to run the business as you please or win a scenario as you please.

Designing the production floor is like a puzzle...but I really hate using that word. It's not a puzzle game. You have to make use of the space you are given (which is a lot so far for me) and plan workflow, but it's much more than that. There are options upon options to consider  The game can be very complex at times, but it also allows the player to keep things simple if they so choose.

There are 8 Scenarios with 5 missions each. Some missions are specific, some are rather broad.  There's also a custom game feature and a free build option. Together, they allow the player to really play as they want. You can develop highly sophisticated medications or you can deal with simple production lines. It's entirely up to you!


2. THE GAME IS POLISHED!

Unlike many indie games, particularly with early access but not exclusive to them, this game is extremely...I mean extremely polished. Everything was very well thought out and organized. Key features were included yet nothing seems to exist that doesn't need to be. ALL the necessary fundamentals you'd expect are here (rare for many games today unfortunately), but many are done exceptionally well and are thus, quite noteworthy.

Examples...

One of the best tutorials I've ever seen in a game - it comes in the form of sections and are repeatable (for those of us who sometimes take a hiatus from a game then return later but forget some of the key controls/mechanics). There are also more in-depth tutorial videos by the dev for those who prefer some serious explanation as to what is going on (most probably won't need it though). The tutorial not only gives you the basics and walks you through the steps (allowing you to learn by doing vs reading a wall-o-text in game), it gives you game strategies such as using dual pill printing and options for varying concentration effects). A lot of thought went into the tutorial here.
Speed controls - should be standard in every game of this sort...but unfortunately many aren't including it. Pause, play, or speed up time here.
Ease of controls - you can hold down key to drag belts and it will auto path and connect where you want. Middle mouse copies an existing machine for further placement, double click allows you to move an existing machine, right click sells a machine.
Convenient linking from one page or pop up to a RELEVANT page or place in the game (such as a an alert for new ingredient having a link to take you to the Ingredients page for convenience if you so choose)
Animations are very well done and relevant to what is happening (fun to watch)
Aesthetic customizer - change colors of belts and floors, you can customize your buildings the way you want.
Contemporary design - very well done design with the gui and game assets. Details like in-game notices are done very well too (sliding from the side at top of page vs simply popping up in the middle of the page or displaying on the right hand side which is what most games seem to do).
Lastly, one of the biggest parts of polish which was noticed...was the lack of any bugs!  I am despearately trying to find some. I know some have to exist. But I so far, have failed to discover any. The game runs smooth and there are no bugs that break immersion or stop gameplay.

The dev did what most other devs do not do today it seems...he focused on QUALITY. He put a substantial amount of time into the game PRIOR to released. He focused on giving customers a QUALITY project to enjoy by making sure the details were there but also that the game works as it is supposed to. He demonstrated that he actually cares about his own game, his own work.

Novel idea huh? Give the players a quality product they expect to have?

3. DEV ACTIVITY

First of all, this is the work of only 1 developer. He, like most devs used outside sources for assets (graphics, sounds, effects, voice), but 1 guy is the brain behind this game. Very few games can be pulled off successfully by a single dev and this one was.

He also is very active in his communication with customers (his own forum, social media, and here at the Steam forums).


THE BAD
I am still struggling to find something. I honestly am. I've not experienced anything negative about this game yet.

The only thing I can see wanting to change, is a part in the last tutorial which discusses maximum strength analysis and how to implement it to upgrade a medicine's rating. To me, that's a bit fuzzy. I tried to understand what was being described and how to pull it off, but didn't understand it. That could just be me though. Regardless, it does not prevent the mission from being completed. It just means the user, or me anyway, needs to ask for clarification on the forum.

SUMMARY / TL;DR
High quality game, extremely polished, plenty of options and features, a lot of variation, NO BUGS (so far). This game will probably become one of the standards of quality that gamers will compare other games to (like many compare other ea games to Prison Architect or Kerbel).

In a sea of poorly designed games from devs who don't seem to either care about their products or have the knowledge to make them great...and with the current gaming community's frustration level at an all-time high due to the abundance of bad games and ripoffs coming out on Steam...let this game refresh your faith and trust in the industry as it is proof that high quality games CAN be delivered and some devs DO care about their project and their customers.

If you enjoy tycoon style games, do yourself a much deserved favor and GET THIS GAME NOW! You will not regret it (especially with Steam's refund policy of course - but you won't need it).

According to description, Big Pharma is a game about creating medicine recipes and selling them for profit. But it focuses more on production process then profit. It is safe to say Big Pharma is a game about creating an efficient production line to achieve your (scenario) goal.

The game has a tutorial, but instead of (usual) series of interactions, tutorial itself is actually a guide-like-text in “tutorial scenarios”. If player can follow the text, it is quite helping and explains the details to a certain degree. Still, for the first few games, it is highly expected that the player will revisit these tutorials. It is also worth noting that the game expects the player to have “planning skills” because it never mentions how a good/efficient layout should be.

In this game, player is given a set of machines, and a number of ingredients. Every ingredient has one curing effect and one to three bad side effects (There are 4 effect slots on each ingredient). Each effect on an ingredient is active on certain “concentration range” and is most effective at a certain concentration. This concentration and activation of effects are the elements that create the base of the game. The player is expected to create a production line using the given machines, to activate the positive effect on an ingredient and create a medicine. Of course, bad side effects are present and are to be avoided. Curing effects on the final medicine increase the value and side effects causes it to lose rating resulting in losing value.

Illnesses and cure recipes are known, and when you produce a medicine, more advance version is unlocked, up to level 5 medicines. Although illnesses and cure recipes are known, ingredients are not. For each game, ingredients are randomly generated. Only things consistent among games are that each ingredient having only one curing effect and activation range of effects. From effect combinations to how much those effects change final medicine’s value is random. This increases replayability value. But it is also random for scenarios; therefore it affects the actual difficulty of the scenarios. One time the game may be too challenging and other time, it may be too easy.

Another randomly generated content is layout for production buildings. In each map, there are several (depending on the size of the map) partitioned buildings. The player is randomly given a partition at the beginning and buys the rest. The buildings and sockets are premade but layout of the buildings is random. Depending on the layout and starting position, the game may be annoying. Annoyance comes from shape of the buildings or the socket positions/count in a partition. Sockets are the points of entry/exit for the ingredients and medicines, on the walls of the buildings. Although there are at least 2 sockets in almost every partition, it can be more. Starting a partition with 4 sockets enables the player to have two production lines, without the need to but new partitions. Also a bad shaped building may prevent you to complete an advance production line required for the higher level medicines.

There are also exploration, research, patenting and “company management”. Research is the common knowledge. Player hires scientists to do research. Research unlocks new machines and some infrastructure projects such as cheaper machine prices or ability of exploring different types of lands. Exploration is the same thing as research but unlocks new ingredients instead. On a normal game, only the most basic machines and only 2 ingredients are available at the start. Rest is unlocked through researching and exploration. That said, researching and exploration are just a tab in the game and not the main focus. Same thing applies for the “company management”. Other than patenting process, company management is just an info tab showing player’s medicines, yearly revenue and profit. Also rivals’ basic info can be seen in company management. There is a research that enables to see detailed info about your rivals but it is pretty much useless. Patenting is what the name suggests. Patenting a medicine prevents the others from selling the same medicine for a limited time. The length of time depends on how much player chooses to spend on the patent.

Rivals in the game serve two purposes. One of them is to cause saturation because they use the same ingredient as the player and produce (mostly) the same medicine. This saturation increases the cost of ingredients and lowers the demand for a specific cure effectively lowering value of medicines. The other purpose is to patent medicine preventing the player to sell the same medicine. Of course the player has access to patenting after researching it too. This creates a nice “patent war” situation in the game, but patenting is pretty expensive and mostly not worth it until late game.

As with all of the production themed games, most of the time in the game will be spend in paused mode. The player will try to make a good choice of ingredient-medicine pair to avoid side effects. After that, he/she will spend an equal time to position each machine in a way that they will occupy the least space. Since it is the nature of the game it is not a bad thing. Still, it is worth noting that machines can only be rotated in 4 directions and belts (connections between the machines) can’t be multi-layered (although they can be crossed and it mostly works well). These limitations may annoy some people, but also some “puzzle people” may welcome them because it gives the production a puzzle feel.

The interface is very well designed and the player is never lost in it. It has a futuristic design and goes well with the game. The sound effects of the game are nice and do not bother the player. But the game is a bit quiet. It needs a few more soundtracks.

Finally, a personal note: Everything in the game is sold back at half the original price. Especially at the beginning, you  may struggle with the design and make lots of mistakes. Buying and selling the belts will cause you to lose lots of money. To prevent this, plan and imagine the whole process in your mind, put all the machines first and then put the belts. It is also possible to get the “free belts” mod from the official site.

Pros:+ Simplistic: All menus and tabs are cleverly put together in a clear and simple manner.
+ Good Formula: Game elements go well together.
+ Fluent gameplay: There is nothing to get in the way during interaction with objects and interface.
+ Mod Support: It does not support workshop but has a separate mod support.

Cons:- Randomization in Campaigns: This results in the campaigns becoming too easy or too hard.
- Crammed Buildings: Sometimes building designs are too narrow or weirdly shaped and they do not allow a good production line.
- Feels Repetitive: Although some of the content is randomized, after a while, the game feels repetitive due to its focus on production. This may be a deal breaker for some people.

Verdict:If you think this game as a production tycoon game -as I did- it is well made (considering this is developed by a one-man-company). Overcoming the challenge to get rid of the bad side effects and creating a high rating medicine gave me enough satisfaction, so I recommend it. But because it focuses on production, it may be insufficient for some people.

P.S: As a rule, I won't comment on price tag. Everyone has a different opinion on whether it is worth the price tag or not. So it is up to you to decide.

reviewText:
I would be wary of reviewers that invest 5 hours or less into this game. The Advanced Mode's machines, along with the Centrifuge from Intermediate, radically increase the ways in which you can manipulate ingredients. It's also much harder to make and maintain a large profit, especially since competitors play a much greater role in the Advanced Mode. You'll need to start utilizing some hidden optimization tricks involving things like the packer or crossing belts with machines that have a cycle time greater than 1. So while dead-simple machine placement will get you through the Beginner and some of the Intermediate Scenarios, reaching Master in the Advanced Scenarios requires a lot more thought.

The negative reviews for this game have some merit, but the game doesn't promise anything more than it delivers. What this game does, it does very well: designing and optimizing production lines, anticipating what the market for a drug will bear, deciding what ingredients and machines to research or upgrade, all while balancing a budget that is very tight early and expands greatly over time. It's a beautifully-animated game that presents a relaxed puzzle atmosphere and gives you almost all of the information you'll need up-front.

Let's get some things out of the way, though. Sick people are abstractions, which is honestly what I'd expect from most Pharmaceutical companies. The larger the market for a cure, the greater the relative price and the more of that cure you can produce without tanking the price. The market can increase or decrease as a result of random world events, increase naturally over time for infectious diseases, and decrease as people are cured. A cure that's particularly potent will fetch a much higher price, but you may eventually be left without a viable market for that product.

The available cures and how they're upgraded are static. The starting concentration of an ingredient has a fairly narrow range based on the range of the Level 1 cure. The number of plots available for purchase, and the sockets within each building layout, are predetermined. On the other hand...The ingredient order is random, side effects are assigned semi-randomly, the building layouts you get are random, and the market for each cure is random within a small range. This can make or break the profitability of several cures, but the Level 1 cure of every starting ingredient is profitable and smart research choices can dig you out of some terrible early setups. Even a terrible cure can fetch a profit, although it can be much lower than you'd get from a perfect cure.

Anyone who says that the Competitors are pointless was playing on one of the easier difficulties. The competition presents a real challenge in Advanced Mode, as you have 3 competitors that all have the same early options that you do. Different AI companies prioritize different things, but they'll usually go for the more profitable cures and cures that can fetch high ratings (ie, no side effects). You have to be smart with your market choices in Advanced because the AI will very quickly oversaturate and tank the price for several cures. Anticipating what your competition will do is a big factor in your success. Patents in particular can really help you or really screw you over in the short-term, although they're fairly easy to work around, but you can do the same thing to the AI. Mucking with the AI's profit margins can really slow them down, giving you a chance to reach (and patent) the very high-level cures before they get a chance to ruin your market.

Sometimes you can make just plain bad choices, but usually there's okay options and really great options. There's almost always something you can optimize more if you put thought into it, and if you're shooting for a certain level of revenue or profit you'll be shifting around production lines a lot. I used to hit patches where I'd just need to wait, but now patch 1.01 added a much-needed 5x speed option!

Personally, I love this game. The progression has a level of predictability that may put some people off, but the random elements that people keep complaining about actually keep things fresh.

reviewText:
Big Pharma is a management/strategy/puzzle game where you have to build and manage a medicine company. You can say it’s a business simulation puzzle tycoon. You build, research, develop new medicine all the while trying to maximize profits. There is one part of the game that focuses on the production aspect of the medicines, in this part you have to concentrate on researching new medicine/cures and try to improve your medicine overall. The second part of the game is the economics of your company. You basically have to earn profit and try to improve medicine.

Graphics:

The graphics are simple yet beautiful looking. The colors are very bright and eye-catching. It almost sort of has that cartoon look. There’s not many options in the graphics menu other than resolution adjustment.

Sound:

The music in the game is okay, you won’t get bored from it but it’s nothing to write home about as well. The announcer voice can sometimes become annoying though. Other than that most of the sounds work as they should and not bad at all.

Gameplay:

The majority of the game is based on missions, where you start out with $50000 and you have a task. For example the first mission has you earn a certain amount of revenue in 10 years. Most of the missions are like that and as you keep doing missions the next batch of missions gets harder and harder. There’s a lot of missions and even free mode where you can just play without having to worry about anything. There will be a rival company which also influences your company when they introduce new drugs etc.

There’s also a puzzle element of fitting your medicine making machinery in a limited space, so figuring that out can be a lot of fun. You can choose from 8 different characters when you start a game. There are perks when you start a new game. E.G a perk where refunding equipment gives you 100% money back instead of regular 50%. You can choose 2 perks, at the beginning there’s only 4 perks unlocked but you can unlock more as you do missions and do the objectives the said perk requires. It’s a very strategic game where everything you do has an effect eventually so you must make your decisions well thought out. Game can be pretty complicated so if you like serious management games, this game is for you.

The DLC “Marketing and Malpractice” adds a whole bunch of add-ons to the game such as marketing tools where you can adjust your prices of your drugs as per the demand/demand, you basic economics. This basically changes they way the game works with your competitors as you can undercut their prices. You can give “gifts” and other such to doctors to increase sales. The DLC in my opinion makes the game much more interesting and gives it that new perspective of playing.

Graphics: 8/10
Sound: 7/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Overall: 8/10

Conclusion:

Big Pharma is an excellent time waster and a very good business/tycoon/simulator/puzzle game. Though prepare to spend plenty of time learning the ins and outs of the game as it can get very complicated. All in all it’s a fun title and the DLC is pretty nice as well.

Played about 60 hours worth of the game so far, and have enjoyed it.  I have compeleted most of the missions offered in the game and have dabbled in the free-play/custom game mode.

Big Pharma is essentially a one part puzzle - one part economic/business simulator, as most of my fellow recommenders have already mentioned.

As it is a two part game, both aspects of it become important at different times.

Early game, the business aspect I feel is the more forefront of the two. Money is tight, and the AI at times can be brutal competitors either flooding the market for a product or squeezing you out of one. Not to say the game is too difficult, but for those who love business simulations, the early game is your niche.  Late game however, the game gives way to its puzzle aspect as the more pressing of the two. You both lose opportunities to flex your capital might as well as simply run out of space to place your production lines, usually resulting in having to forgo certain markets alltogether just to produce a high tier product. And one that is impossible to optimize at that. Some of the late game markets are quirky too  I feel - The Male Contraception treatments are apparently permanent (in any form, but pill form specifically just boggles my mind).

For those who love business simulations though, I'd recommend giving the game a go.  Its drawbacks to me are more quirky than actual problems with the game itself and you can get decent value from the game at its listed price.

In addition, I tink Mark Allsworth did a decent job with the games soundtrack.

reviewText:
Big Pharma is a tycoon-style game based around pharmaceutical development. It holds the isometric view of classic games like Rollercoaster Tycoon while being graphically sleek. As with its tycoon-style roots, it also contains puzzle elements as the equipment you must use act as puzzle pieces that you must fit together in a fixed amount of space.

So what makes this game appealing?
Firstly, it's a management simulation game. If you're as big a fan as Rollercoaster Tycoon as I am, chances are you'll enjoy this game just on the style of the game alone.

As for how the levels are set up, there are several categories of scenarios each with their own set missions. These categories range from Beginner to Advanced difficulties, along with Quick Play and Crippling Debt categories, the last of which severely handicaps you if you're looking for a challenge!

When it comes to dropping into a scenario, the building space and ingredients you have at your disposal are completely randomized. This means you can start the game with a nice area to start building in, or perhaps a not so nice area. It also means that you can have ingredients that induce negative side effects or not. But no fear! You can buy more space with the money you have and discover more ingredients through exploring different biomes for new raw materials to make cures to illnesses with so overcoming a rough start is entirely doable.

Exploring for new ingredients is a must as well as researching new methods to manipulate the drugs to turn them into cures. The ingredient system works very well in my opinion. Sometimes you just have to change the concentration of the ingredient to make higher level cures but sometimes you also need to mix it just right with catalysts to make the drug a higher selling product which adds more layers of depth to production.

With all that, there are also competitors that influence the drug market in their own unique way that isn't the same each time you play. Competitors may release the same drug as you have, saturating the market with supply which brings the price of the drug down a little. So release patents to stop them and hope they don't do the same to you!

This game, while simple at its core, offers a great managing experience and varying levels of challenge even within each mission through three different win-states. The win-states are like a Bronze

I've been playing this game since its early beta days back in June 2015. Big Pharma might look like your run of the mill tycoon game, but it is much deeper than that.

The concentration system for drugs, the random ingrediant generation and robust AI compeditor performance (especially on higher difficulty levels) lends this to be a very interesting and *very* replayable game. Sure the random nature might mean that the available ingrediants are awesome in one game and suck in the next...but since everybody in the game plays with the same pool of ingrediants, the challenge is to make the most of what is available.

This is also a part puzzle game as you try to figure out how to cram your more and more complex production lines into a limited space. It can be extremely satisfying to have nearly every square inch of an area filled to the brim with drug machinery humming with their various drug modifying operations.

The tech tree is laid out in a logical but still strategic manner. Researching techs takes scientists and keeping scientists employed is expensive, so deciding which techs to go for in which order is important. Given the variable ingrediants each game, you aren't going to always want the same path down the tech tree each game. Not to mention you have to weight the options of leaving your scientists idle, which generates research points that are used to upgrade your equipment (making it cheaper to operate) or use them to research new techs, giving you access to brand new equipment or other discounts.

If you are a fan of business tycoon games at all, this game is for you. It is absolutely worth the price of admission.

reviewText:
Big Pharma is obviously a business management sim, but it has some unique things going for it that distinguish it from other types of business management sims and give it a unique hook.

First let's discuss the normal business management aspects. You run a company that makes drugs, and there are essentially three areas of the company you have to manage. The first is that you need the space and the equipment to make the drugs, which means you will need to spend capital to purchase floor space and then you will need to spend more capital to purchase machines to go on that floor space that are used to make your drugs. (There is a LOT more complexity to this part of the game, but we'll get into that later.) The second area is research, which is pretty much just an unlock tree. You pay an initial flat rate to hire a scientist and then also pay each scientist by the hour. The more scientists you have on payroll, the more quickly you'll rack up research points, but that obviously gets expensive, so you need to balance with your income. Research unlocks new machines, new shipping methods, access to new drug recipes, ability to file patents on your recipes, and more. The third area is exploration, which is a tree similar to the research tree. In this area you pay a flat rate to hire explorers and then also pay them by the hour. You deploy your explorers to search jungles, deserts, oceans, etc for new or rare ingredients. By discovering new ingredients with new properties, you have access to new recipes that can be used to make a variety of new drugs. Explorers also have their own research points which you can spend to reduce the purchase price of ingredients and reduce your cost of materials.

These are the basics. Know that you will always have rival companies that are manufacturing and selling drugs in competition with you, and if the rival company's drugs are of a better quality than yours, they can eat up your market share (i.e. you will make fewer sales and earn less money due to your competitor stealing your customers). In the early modes and difficulties, competitors are a breeze to deal with. They can be more of a menace in later modes, though, for sure.

Okay, so what is the unique hook? The unique hook lies in purchasing floor space and machines and then assembling production lines. It is a complicated PUZZLE. Bear with me, because this gets a tad complex. Every ingredient you have to work with has four effect slots, and those four slots are filled with effects. The slots can either contain a curative effect, a negative effect, or simply be empty. The easiest ingredients to work with tend to have one curative effect and one negative effect. The more difficult ingredients have one curative effect and three negative effects. In addition to these effect slots, each ingredient also has a CONCENTRATION value that can be anywhere between 1 and 20. The higher the number, the higher the concentration. Each of the effects in the four slots has a random concentration interval assigned to it, and the effect is only ACTIVE if the concentration falls within that interval. For example, if the ingredient has the curative effect SOOTHES COLD that is active between 11-14, and the negative effect CAUSES CONSTIPATION that is active between 5-12, and the default concentration of the ingredient is 12, then THAT means that both effects are active in the ingredient, so you have to put the ingredient through a machine that will change the concentration so that the curative effect is active and the negative effect is not active. So if you change the concentration to 13, it is still within range to soothe colds, but it will no longer cause constipation. Get it? Still with me? It gets even crazier.

Okay, so obviously there are machines that can change the concentration value of an ingredient to alter the effects. But sometimes you have ingredients with three negative effects and it is literally impossible to deactivate all of the negative side effects, so then what do you do? Well, there are also machines that can shake up the order of the effect slots, and machines that can swap effects between two ingredients. So if you're clever, you can swap negative effects out and positive effects in. In some situations, you can even create super drugs that have multiple positive effects! The problem is that it can require a lot more machines to make these crazy drugs, which is not only more expensive to purchase the machines, but each machine also has a per-use cost as well, so it is in your best interest to have as few machines as possible. reviewText:
My fear in purchasing this was that I'd be bored of it in 5 minutes.  I'm glad to say that I was wrong.

Don't be fooled by the simple, clean UI---Big Pharma is a surprisingly deep simulator where the logistical puzzle of placing machinery to assemble your drugs is the least of your worries.  For me, the real difficulty of the game was interacting with the drug market, where you must balance drug prices, market saturation & also keep an eye on what your competitors are doing (if they're importing the same ingredient as you, for example, that ingredient may become oversaturated & its price will rise, hurting your bottom line).

You can flood the market with a side effect-laden drug for some quick cash if you want, but consumers will eventually figure it out & punish you as your cure rating drops & your drug starts losing money.

My only criticism of the game so far is that it lacks a planning stage where you can lay out your production lines in advance.  I had to repeatedly switch between the Ingredients & Cures tabs to work out how to develop a level 3 cure, and keeping track of the machines that I needed quickly became overwhelming.  In the end, I'd go to the Production tab to place a couple machines, then back to the Ingredients & Cures tabs to figure out what machines to place next.

A planning stage that tells you the concentrations/catalysts of imported ingredients (from the Ingredients tab), how to get to the cure (from the Cures tab) & the concentration/catalyst of the drug as it exits each machine in the planned line would be incredibly useful.  Then click a button to commit the entire thing, and you're done.

Also, when I'm deciding which machines to upgrade, it'd be very helpful to know how many of that machine I have across all my production lines.  For now, I can scan the lines to get a rough idea, but this is another example of mental gymnastics that the game could eliminate.

Big Pharma is a game that I wouldn't hesitate to pick up on sale.  I'll be following this one for sequels/expansions.

(This review was for version 1.00.04 of the game.)

reviewText:
Big Pharma is a logistics min/max puzzle game mixed with a lightweight market simulation.  You'll make decisions regarding the quality of your cures vs. the strength of their side effects vs. the profit margins you get for selling them vs. the randomly-generated sized and shaped warehouses available to build in.

To go along with this, you'll have to work through a Research tree to gain access to better equipment and new ingredients as well as many ways to discount the various costs and/or efficienices in the game.  The better equipment is needed for making higher-end cures as well as making cures with less overall machines that might require more creative conveyor belt routing.  Some machines do take more turns to complete an action so now I need to build another conveyor line going this way and then bring them back together over here and then I just need to...  ahem...

There's also an Ingredients tree where you'll send explorers to various places to unlock the ability to cure other diseases.  Some of these ingredients have special catalysts that you'll need to use to upgrade other ingredients.  Upgrading lets you develop cures for the more difficult and expensive diseases to treat.  All ingredients have side effects though that can vary widely - adding another layer of difficulty.  Inactive explorers will help you reduce the costs of your ingredients as well so you can bring up your profit margins without having to sacrifice a cure's quality because that stupid jerk other company is stealing my marketshare and my patent won't finish for another three months and staying in the green is tough right now so I just need to... ahem...

The game's main story mode has a really great variety of challenges to play through.  The tutorial levels are a spot-on introduction to the game and do a good job of preparing the player for the regular game.  The difficulty does ramp up pretty quickly between the columns - especially when there are additional competitors in the game.  Some of the levels are really straight-forward and you'll knock them out in no time flat.  Other levels are like trying to eat frosted mini-wheat cereal without milk, for lunch, while sprinting across the Sahara Desert being chased by whatever crazy hallucinations the sun poisoning has developed because writing this review is going on too long now so I just need to... ahem...

Go play some more!

Tldr; This is one of those games that makes me physically stop and ensure I don't have anything else going on for the next 2-7 hour long binge session.

This key was obtained from the developer for review purposes.

Summary:
A surprisingly deep experience in the strategy genre. The game hits you over the head with the options for the custom game. Granted, it'll take a bit of time to understand all the elements the game, and the tutorial could be better at teaching you the game's elements. But once you get an understanding of everything the game has to offer, you'll find surprising depth. The game's strategy design is where it shines: what elements are adjustable and ones that are not are done with purpose and reason in my opinion. Dealing with competitors that actually can affect your gameplay in slight and even more direct ways was fun, and it made me a bit sad that there's no MP element of the game, as I really felt like the game could have truly shined there. When it comes down to it: I felt this game did something that I feel a lot of developers could learn from: start with a great base design, add the options later on, and designed it from the player's angle: and what they'd want. Rather impressed in the long run, and can recommend to strategy gamers out there.


Gameplay Footage and Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=poYuUF9spzM

Lists:
+:
Lots of customization options in terms of gameplay, and in particular with the custom game. Really can change the elements down to the most specific growth rates and research trees that are available. A lot of strategy games can learn from this level of customization.
I cover strategy games rarely because of the type of player that I am (I'm the builder type, basically consider me the opposite of the zerg play style), but this game was right up my alley in terms of my game style, but other game styles as well.
Good balance of gameplay elements that don't overly punish you for not using them, but reward you for taking advantage of them. Cost vs effectiveness of the drug does make a difference, especially in the early going, but both strategies can be viable.
Found that it stood the test of time in terms of variety with the smaller elements. Despite me restarting a lot due to my own personal weaknesses (aka wanting to perfect situations and so repeatedly starting again), I still found myself having fun.
This may seem weird to say, but some of the elements that you'd expect that aren't there (like setting the price of the drug)
Actually like the restricted playing fields. Causes you to have your own puzzle mini-game regarding machine placement that works rather well.
Did I mention there's a good selection of options? There's a good selection of options.
There's apparently mod support. That's always a plus.
-:
Takes a bit of time to get going in terms of understanding. Lots of information to digest, and it could have been passed on to the player easier in the end. Tutorial could have been done better.
Little rough around some of the edges. In particular with things like the belt controls feel like that there may have been a better implementation. Luckily, it's something that you can easily get adjusted to in time.
Would have loved to see a MP version of the game, but understand the development costs that would be required in order for that to happen.

reviewText:
Overview
I have played for over 30 hours without mods or cheats and do not own the expansion pack. So far I have managed to progress to Intermediate level in the scenarios. From my experience this game is what a sim management should be.  With a bit of twisted humour thrown into the mix seen in classics such as Theme Hospital, Big Pharma is beautifully made and very entertaining with a lot of replayability.

Interface and graphics
The main menu looks like a mobile port but don't be fooled! The simplistic buttons and side menus in the main game add to the overall functionality of the game. There are options to change the resolution, sound and graphic quality in the game. The graphics are in the cartoon style. I personally prefer this because cartoon style graphics will age much slower than the more realistically styled games, if at all.

Gameplay
There are 3 game modes for you to play - Free Play, Custom Game and Scenario. Free Play is the sandbox level where every machine and research branch is already unlocked and you have no money. Custom Game is where you set your own criteria to win the game. All of the goals/criteria in the game are number based and it would be nice to have a little more variety in how you win like being the most or least ethical competitor in game (but this might be in the expansion). Other than that the gameplay is solid. There is a lot of scope for replayability. There are 3 ranks in each game: standard, expert and master. The higher up the rank, either you have to do more within the standard time limit, or you have a shorter amount of time to complete your criteria. It's not just about what the game tells you to do as I find that I set myself personal goals long after I have finished my game criteria on a certain level.

A few funny bugs
I have experienced some world events that were not logical at certain times. An example of this is the 'mild winter' event that popped up in May. I was also stuck on the 'Keep calm and carry on' scenario for a bit because none of the raw ingredients that were available to be explored in the game had the certain enzyme that I needed to be able to upgrade my drug to an anti-anxiety treatment. I made sure to explore all of the available areas.

My verdict
This is a great game. It gets really addictive so don't pick this game up if you want to be productive. A solid 10.

reviewText:
Have played a lot of this game before it reached Steam. It has a very tycoon feel to it while being very puzzle like in the builds. It currently has 35 different challenge senarios that all have randomly generated buildings and ingredients with randomly generated possitives and negitives each time you start a new challenge so you can very much play the same challenge over and over and get an entirely different play through each and every time. The machines mechanics are for the most part well expained though there are some things that you learn by just doing.

And say you don't like any of the scenarios or have beaten the master rank (basicly gold in a gold/silver/bronze rating system) of all the scenarios (which would take a long time to do even if your great at the game)  custom game has a ton of customization to it, choose anywhere from 0-3 competitors, 5-15 randomly generated ingredients, where you start with 2-5, how many catilist there are and their side effects, victory conditions of total revenue, operating profit, within x years, x products with atleast x profit or value or level, minimun cure rating, total products, and pay off loan, which you can combine in any fation, so say you want the winning condition to be where you have to have 3 pills that all make atleast $1,000 profit per pill produced all with atleast B cure rating within 15 years with no competitors, you can do that. You can also set what research you (and all competitors) start with and even what research is disabled in the game (so say you don't want anybody to be able to make patents you can disable patents).

Then you get into settings like map size, event frequency, loan interest rates, plot cost, research speed, scientist saleries, scientiest hire cost, explorer saleries and hire costs, analyzing speed, patent speed, patent cost, cure market size, cure profit margins, starting money, starting loan, ingredient prices, process costs, build costs, research point accrual speed, ingredient point accrual speed, cure rate, infection rate... and all of these things don't have just like 5 settings, they are all sliders that have many many settings even if its not good at informing that well (for example plot cost you could set to where it says low and the first land may cost $500, but then you set it again in low but slightly in a different slider cost and now it costs $480 or $620 for the first one.

Between the randomly generated buildings, the randomly generated ingredients, the number of custom challenges with 3 ratings that are fairly challenging to get the best rank on, and the sheer customability of custom games, you will find that this game is very replayable even doing the same challenge or even same custom game settings because even with the exact same custom settings the buildings and ingredients are randomly generated each time which also means what the competitors make which effects your profit margins also changes each time. And can be as challenging or easy as you want it to be. And even as quick or long as you want it to be depending on how you set all the custom game sliders and victory conditions.

reviewText:
This is a clever little simulation game. The challenge comes in two forms. The first is a business management simulation, not unlike Theme Hospital or similar games. The second part of the game is a spacial puzzle. It starts out simply enough. Very simple production lines bring ingredients in and pump packaged drugs out with a few steps along the way to prepare the formula. As you progress in the game you will unlock many new ingredients and cures and technology used to prepare them.

Initially, the game only offers you selections that are available at the current level. As such, the game appears quite basic on the surface for the first dozen or so scenarios. As you progress further in to the game, however, you unlock a great deal of new research projects and technology.

Many of the negative reviews I am seeing for the game (not all, but many) are suggesting the game is very basic and has a short lifespan. These same reviews were mostly written by players who had between 2 and 6 hours of play time recorded. I suspect most of these players didn't even play long enough to see how much added complexity there is when you unlock patents and stage 4 cures, etc.

Highly recommended to programmers or anyone who enjoys optimizing engines. The production line component of the is reminiscent of SpaceChem.

Don't be fooled by the hours played, I've put in at least 30 hours in the beta phase (outside steam).

The good: Solid gameplay, in depth strategy combined with tactical considerations like space and use of import/export sockets, excellent replayability with custom level builder and sandbox mode
Awesome graphics, animations and perfectly suited music. Watching your factory and drugs in motion is mesmerizing!

No 'missing' features that gamers are forced to pay again for in the form of DLC or add-ons. The game is complete on release.The bad:Umm maybe a bit difficult for new players to grasp? It's honestly not a difficult game but it's definitely a step up from the mindless clicking that most casual games ask for these days.As I was typing this I realized that expecting a game dev to put out a polished, feature complete game at release has become somewhat of a high expectation in the industry :(
Big Pharma definitely meets it and then some! I do hope there may be some sort of expansion/sequel in the future but this is certainly not a game that is lacking content. Like the good old tycoon/city builder games of the 90s, Big Pharma doesn't hold your hand. Understanding the mechanics takes all of an hour or so but mastering the game is not so easy!

I'd recommned this game to tycoon fans, puzzle fans and those that like to relax with their games.

reviewText:
Big Pharma is a great game for everyone who likes planning, tweaking, optimization.
Your task is to manage a pharma corporation by producing and selling drugs. To get the job done, you´ll find your self searching for the required ingredients that can be processed and transformed into almost endless varieties as you increase or decrease concentration, add ingredients to produce new treatments and upgrade their effects.
To make things more difficult, almost all ingredients have side effects that you may remove, weaken, avoid (by manipulating concentration) or just accept as a necessary evil - but beware, strong side effects will lower your drug rating and value.

To make matters more complicated, your factory equipment cannot be placed neatly into straight assembly lines - each machine type has its own layout and creating complex chains will indeed be a puzzle game. And things usually don´t stay in place once you add new options to your arsenal - I find myself frequently redesigning my factory layout to optimize it according to the newly unlocked machines (which you can research).

All the while, different scenarios and settings require you to work towards a variety of different objectives, from just making cash to delivering a super-drug with high value.


To sum it up:  This game makes you think! If you like complex problem solving tasks, this is definitely your game.

I've been playing Big Pharma via a non-Steam version and have been really enjoying it. I'd played at least a dozen hours before the 1.0 release and have been very please with how the developer has not only been regularly updating the game, but also responding to community inputs and making changes based on them.

I'd have to say that it's partly a puzzle game, in that you have to build assembly lines that require some planning and tinkering to fit them in the available space and also to spend as little money as possible. And you have to research more efficient (abet more costly) production machines that take up less space.

It's also a business sim, in that you buy resourses, process them and then produce a product. This is done very well in the game because you don't have to stare at spreadsheets, instead you can just mouse over the production lines or your company page and the appropriate info is right there. And it's very easy to understand where you are making and losing money, in fact I'd say that this game is one of the best examples of how to make a business sim right.

And the other nice feature that I like is that the game is composed of a number of scenarios/missions, most of which have three different levels of victory, and you don't have to unlock any particular mission to play any other of them. Plus there's also a custom game mode, where you can alter all sorts of criteria and conditions, and a free build mode where you can just make assembly lines and geek out on that.

The game is very polished and glitch and bug free. I very much recommend it.

reviewText:
Big Pharma is a very refreshing take on factory building that offers genuine satisfaction for coming up with the best production line you can think of.  Where similar games get by overloading with content and chaos--more things to build, higher volume, etc, Big Pharma rewards for elegant solutions.  It isn't about how much you produce.  It's about how you produce it.

For simplicity's sake, I will contrast Big Pharma with Factorio, which I also got a lot of enjoyment from.  Factorio is about managing resources and logistics--incredibly large numbers of exceedingly simple tasks that combine to create hectic situations.  The entire game (Factorio) can be summed up as deciding what you want to make, then ensuring the right buildings are getting the right amounts of all requisite materials in a massive and complicated chain involving dozens of buildings.  All gameplay revolves around that.

Big Pharma is absolutely nothing like that; rather, it is about design and decision making.  Where Factorio gets complicated, Big Pharma is merely complex.  In Big Pharma, you can make whatever sort of cure you like.  Expensive or cheap, whether you earn or lose money is determined by *how* you chose to make the product and whether it was a wise choice to make it at all considering demand, competition, and your current capabilities.  You can make crazy wonder drugs and lose money with a hasty production line a la Factorio, or you can put some thought into it and make millions.  The same applies to the cheap drugs.  Maybe you even allow a minor, negative side effect in the product to ensure economic viability.  It's up to you to determine what the right move is, and when you make that right move, you get genuine satisfaction out of it that games like Factorio are simply incapable of matching.

I am not saying that Big Pharma is better than Factorio.  I got a lot more time out of Factorio than I did from Big Pharma.  But I do believe the time I spent with Big Pharma was more enjoyable and satisfying, which is quite fitting.  Production in Factorio is all about volume, and production in Big Pharma is all about quality and substance.  This mirrors my gameplay experience with the two games quite nicely.

reviewText:
A tycoon/simulator game where you build production lines for medicine. There is no story mode/campaign but rather many scenarios that require you to reach a certain objective (like a target revenue) within a time limit.

You start with an open area and have to build production lines for medicine. You start with a vent on the wall to import raw ingredients, pass it through several processing machines to refine and produce the medicine, then end with a vent on the wall to export the completed product. There are a variety of machines and you'll have to make decisions on how to make your medicine. There are tradeoffs in space, manufacturing speed, profit, and quality of medicine based on which and how many machines you use. Also, there is a research system in place that requires you to invest money to eventually unlock more ingredients, machines, and other bonuses,

Certain things could be better polished/presented:
The tutorial could be better- it's just one long scrollable text box. I would've liked a tutorial that was properly divided into separate windows for each step and with UI focus (like highlighting/pointer arrows, etc.) on what is being talked about. It's not too hard to learn if you've played similar games or have a knack with understanding program UI but the tutorial could use some polishing up.
At first glance it seemed that there were only 4 columns of challenges but one day I was surprised when my mouse cursor wandered to the right edge of the screen and it scrolled a little. There's no reason to move your mouse all the way to the right (you can hover over the right-most challenges without scrolling the screen)
Sometimes it's hard to click on a specific thing (like vents to change ingredients or to delete specific tiles of that are partially hidden behind things). It's due to perspective but there has to be some way to better select objects in the back. You have to click on a certain area for vents that you'll have to learn by experience.
There are a couple UI changes I would have liked:
To have a dedicated area to see current active events. I couldn't find the details anywhere after I dismissed the event box. After a while you can manually check the graphs for the changes but it would still be a nice addition.
To toggle ingredient icons while zoomed out (normally, all icons disappear). I liked to use the icons to figure out which areas are making which product (which is useful when you want to change production).
To find the location of your product line by clicking on the product in your company tab
To display the amount of ingredient currently being used in the upgrade tooltip (like the machine upgrade tooltip). This would let you know at a glance which ingredient you're using a lot (so how much the upgrade would benefit you).
'Auto pause and focus' is nice but it will sometimes not work if you've currently opened another event window. Your product line (and its revenue) will stop completely while it waits for you to name a product so the product naming window should really always pause and force you to deal with it (Or the product should keep selling under the generic name until you name it).
Personally, I would've liked a campaign or scenarios with personalities and scripted events to make things interesting. A little story to link things together helps keep my interest when doing multiple playthroughs of the same thing. The sandbox is fun for a while but it's not like The Sims where it's easy to make your own story in the sandbox. I had fun doing a few challenges and then went straight to a custom game with all tier levels unlocked to get the full experience.

Worth a look if you like sandbox tycoon games and refining your strategy through multiple playthroughs.

Big Pharma is a fantastic management and simulation game. It's an usual subject to be managing, but now that I've played the game I'm surprised that it took this long for someone to think of it!

The game is a great balance of logic puzzle (in the form of making profitable drugs), business (deciding when to expand, when to invest, when to do nothing), and simulation of the pharmaceutical industry. I played this when it was first released in beta and it is a LOT better since that point, so if you read about the previous releases and weren't sure I'd suggest looking at a more recent review before deciding to buy. It's a great example of an early access game doing what you would hope: improving in the run up to release and being a better product when it gets there.

Positech has a great history of supporting and developing games post-release, and I look forward to playing this game for a long time to come with more and better things to do in it.

reviewText:
See what it feels like to be Martin Shkreli, in this pharmaceutical company management sim, ... well maybe not. In Big Pharma you do manage a pharmaceutical company but it's more of a puzzle game with management elements.

Big part of the gameplay is placing various machines that increase or decrease concentration of ingredients or mix them up and finally turn them into pills or creams or syringes. All these machines have different input and output locations and often sizes, you also need to add conveyor belts and with limited amount of space and doors through which ingredients can enter and leave your factory creating a new drug becomes, well a puzzle. Besides planning your factory you'll send explorers in search of new ingredients and researchers to invent new types of machines or improve existing ones.

You can play in free mode or one of many challenges. What is really smart and should be adopted in other games is that the challenges get progressively more complex. And I don't mean that the competition gets tougher or you are hit with arbitrary debuffs. The game actually limits your research tree and ingredient list to only present you with simple choices. Then as you progress you are given more and more options. It's a really nice game that hits that improvement itch, you've created a cure for bad breath and now you can improve it and cure sore throat. Coming up with more and more complex recipes for more advanced cures is extremely satisfying.

Dad rating: Excellent
Game can be paused at any time, giving you time to attend to the little ones. Speed can also be increased if you prefer to breeze through the more boring periods.
No violence what so ever. No scary monsters jumping out on the screen either. You can safely play it with your child on your knees.
I highly recommend it my 10h with Big Pharma felt like a breeze and I'm looking forward to many more.
